Fields.DialogueText: Bezbozhnik? Are you there?
We're two weeks out, and I've barely seen you.
[violin music]
Bezbozhnik?

Fields.MenuText: Where are you?
Come out here at once!
Hello? Bezbozhnik?

Fields.DialogueText: Hey, where'd you go?
*ALARM*
We've got a skittish Belle and an enemy engagement, huh?
Must be a day that ends in Y.
@BATTLE
[violin music]
...You're staring again, Captain.
D'you always do that to the new kid?
What? No.
You seemed nervous. I wanted to put you at ease, and...

Fields.MenuText: I wanted to get to know you.
I wanted to see if you'd spot me.
I didn't want you to stop playing.

Fields.DialogueText: Funny way of showing it, but I'll forgive you.
Well, I did. Gold stars all around.
... Thank you, Captain. But it's not necessary.
We're both here to do a job. I assumed you'd want me to cut the chatter.
You assumed wrong. You're part of the crew, aren't you?
Technically, I'm part of the propulsion mechanism. Or maybe the armaments.
Less technically, you're our ship's Belle. And that means part of my job is getting to know you.
*ALARM*
Another part of your job is giving orders, Captain.
To the bridge, then.
Hm.
@BATTLE
Do you take requests?
Ah, the musician's curse.
A heavy burden to bear, I know.
I don't mind. But no hymns, Captain.
Right. Bezbozhnik means "atheist," doesn't it?
Yes. Yes, it does.

Fields.MenuText: Following the party line, I see?
I won't step on your toes if you don't step on mine.
Sensible. There's no proof for any other viewpoint.

Fields.DialogueText: I believe what I believe, Captain.
Same to you, Captain.
... No, there isn't.
Hmmm. Do you know any Russian folk songs?
.... No, Captain. Try something else.
But you're a Russian Belle, technically. Shouldn't you-
*ALARM*
... Damn witches.
We'll take care of them. Battle stations, everyone!
@BATTLE
Captain?
Ah! You snuck up on me.
Hm.
I wanted to apologize for the other day. For not knowing any Russian songs.
There's nothing to apologize for.
It's a smaller symptom of a larger problem.
Do you know my story, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: You weren't always a Russian Belle, right?
Aren't you a defector?
The briefing was censored to all hell.

Fields.DialogueText: Hah! Something like that.
... No, Captain.
My bosses do like their secrecy.
I started my life as a British sub. They called me L-55. - This was before we woke up, of course.
I don't think they'd name a ship anything like that now. It's dehumanizing.
Not sure that matters, Cap.
... Anyway. I was sunk in Russian waters during the Great War. The Red Fleet dredged me up. Fixed me up.
And then I woke up.
... With a Scots accent and holes in my memory you could steer a cruiser through.
I see. The Russian navy isn't sure whether they can trust you.
Exactly. But they need me. So here we are.
You've found yourself in a strange position, haven't you?
Hmph. You can say *that* again.
Well, be that as it may.
The Neutrality Fleet is just that. Neutral. I'm not going to judge you based on your origins or your nationality.
All that matters is how well you can protect the sea from Morganas. And you've proven you excel at that.
Thank you, Captain.
*ALARM*
Here's another chance to prove myself.
Believe me, you already have.
@BATTLE
Brr. If we never stop in Siberia again, it'll be too soon.
We need a samovar for the coffee room. It warms you right up.

Fields.MenuText: We have a coffee pot and a kettle, isn't that enough?
I hate tea.
I'll think about it. Rationing is a pain.

Fields.DialogueText: Do you also hate kittens and sunshine?
Blechh. Coffee is just not the same.
Of course. Every bit of metal's for the People.
It doesn't matter. Even if we get one, we're not getting it for a while.
Hey, I've been meaning to ask...
Hit me, Captain.
Is there anyone who could get you up to speed on Russian culture?
I've known a couple defectors, and if they make a good effort to learn... people accept them more.
I'm not a defector, Captain.
You know what I mean, though.
I do. And ... well....
There's my daughters, Captain.
The Leninets-class subs. They were modeled on me, and they look up to me.
Since we woke up, they try to limit our contact. For obvious reasons. I am a Western influence.
Well, maybe you can write to them? They can censor your letters if you start talking about Coca-Cola.
You have a point, Captain.
*ALARM*
I'll give it a go. *After* we deal with this.
Good idea.
@BATTLE
Captain? Can you help me with something?
Of course! ...I think this is the first time I've seen you on the bridge outside of a battle.
Hm, is that so?
I need you to send a letter for me the next time we make landfall.
Oh, is it to your daughters?
To Stalinets, yes.

Fields.MenuText: What does it say?
Do you want me to look over it for you?
Do you think you'll get in trouble?

Fields.DialogueText: No. I just can't leave the ship. Who knows what kind of mail service they'll have out here?
That won't be necessary, but thank you.
Hmmm, well...
It's nothing that will fluff feathers. I asked after her health and if she has any folk songs she likes.
Let's hope it's innocuous enough for your bosses.
It ought to be, but...
*ALARM*
They just don't know when to quit.
Neither do we, Captain!
@BATTLE
Bezbozhnik? We've made landfall.
Oh. That's good news.
I'm going to send your letter now.
You remembered? Hm.
Of course I did.

Fields.MenuText: You needed help, I gave it.
If I can't keep you happy, I can't keep you running smoothly.
You deserve to talk to your daughters.

Fields.DialogueText: Hm. Understood, Captain.
Thank you.
I did. But to be honest, I'm used to being self-reliant.
You must miss your daughters a lot.
Oh, you have no idea. I miss them every day.
Did you hear that Leninets took down an entire Morgana fleet with two torpedoes?
And Stalinets' kill count is over sixty-five Morganas! At this rate she might beat SM U-35.
I'm so proud of her...
Sometimes I forget you're not human, and then you drop something like this.
Heh.
What?
What do you mean?
Most mothers aren't proud of their daughters' kill counts.
Well, they're not most daughters!
*ALARM*
Time to raise your own kill count, hm?
Thought you'd never ask.
@BATTLE
Hey, Bezbozhnik - you've got a letter.
Oh? Who's it from?
Who do you think?
Stalinets!
Yep. Here you go.
*poof*
Bezbozhnik? Where'd you go?
It feels kind of skinny. Should I be worried?
You won't know til you open it.

Fields.MenuText: I hate the way they teleport...
You can come out now!
I hope she's all right...

Fields.DialogueText: *ALARM*
Someone go find Bezbozhnik!
Yes, sir.
@BATTLE
There you are! We've been looking all over for you.
I'm sorry, Captain. I reacted badly to some bad news.

Fields.MenuText: About your daughters?
About the new posting?
About the Motherland?

Fields.DialogueText: Things seem fine on that front, Captain.
Oh, no, I'm used to being posted to the back end of nowhere.
Exactly, Captain.
Stalinets said I'm not to talk to her. The Rear Admiral of her fleet was very insistent.
But she's your daughter, isn't she?
Do you think that matters?
If I'm a security risk, then I'm a security risk. I could be the Virgin Mary and they wouldn't tell me anything--
-- Blyat.
... I see what you mean.
There's something strange about this letter, though. Stalinets capitalized random letters. See?
Do you think it's supposed to be a code?
If it is, it doesn't spell out any words.
But there has to be more to it than that, doesn't there?
I'm sure you'll figure it out eventually.
*ALARM*
It'd be easier to figure it out without these witches on our case.
@BATTLE
Still trying to crack that code, Bezboznik?
Yes, Cap.
Are you having fun?
It's giving me grief, but I'll crack it.
I don't think it's a substitution cipher. There's not enough characters for that.

Fields.MenuText: Are you sure it's not just a typing error?
You really care about your daughters.
If I can do anything to help...

Fields.DialogueText: Of course I do. They are my daughters.
Stalinets is a smart girl. If she'd mistyped once, I could believe that, but there's too many mistakes here.
Thank you, Captain. You've been far too kind to me.
It's the least I can do. You've had a strange, rough life. And yet...
You're so determined to take care of them.
I have to believe she wants to talk to me. As much as I want to talk to her.
They only exist because of me. I brought them into the world. So I have a duty.
I just wish we weren't so... constrained.
I do, too.
They won't even give us proper heat.
I keep telling you, Captain, we need-
A samovar, I know, I know.
*ALARM*
We need more Morganas like we need a hole in the head.
I couldn't agree more.
@BATTLE
Hey, Bezbozhnik. I have bad news and worse news, which do you want first?
Worst first.
We're going to be stationed in the Arctic Circle for the foreseeable future.
Ah, doing piss-all in the back end of nowhere? Why am I not surprised?

Fields.MenuText: That seems to be your lot in life.
We go where the Fleet sends us.
You’ve seen the reports of Morgana traffic up there.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, when your commanders don't trust you, they put you somewhere where you can't ruin anything.
Somehow, I think my bosses had more to do with this than anyone else.
Yes. I’m sure the white-fronted geese are terrified.
Be that as it may, I'm sure there will be enough Morganas to keep it interesting.
Here's to hoping. - Out of curiosity, what's the bad news?
I regret to inform you...
Yes, Captain?
...We're going to have to get a samovar.
Oh, Cap, that's *fantastic* news!
... But it won't arrive until our next shore leave. After we've had to deal with all of... this nonsense.
Ugh, you got my hopes up.
How goes the codebreaking?
Well-
*ALARM*
Just my luck. Tell you later!
@BATTLE
It's so cold I can see my breath... The engine room should be warmer.
[violin music]
Bezbozhnik? Where are you?
Over here, Captain.
You found the one warm place on board, didn't you?
Yes, Captain. Can't play violin with mittens on, can you?
I wouldn't want to try.
Me neither. You could damage the poor thing.
Brrr. That's no good.
Are you still cold, Captain? Do you want me to warm you up?

Fields.MenuText: Well...
How do you mean?
Not as cold as death, right?

Fields.DialogueText: No shame in it, Captain.
Oh, don't look so scandalized, I'm just going to hug you.
... Captain, don't joke like that.
Here I come-
Oof! You hug like a bear.
Sorry, Cap. It's just... I can't remember the last time I had a hug.
It's all right. I got you. I got you.
*ALARM*
They just *have* to ruin the mood.
It's their M.O., I guess. Let's get back to the deck?
Blegh. Back into the cold.
@BATTLE
Captain! I think I've done it!
Done what?
I cracked the code.

Fields.MenuText: There *was* a code after all?
You're a mad genius.
I knew you could do it.

Fields.DialogueText: Cap, I thought you trusted me. Of course there was a code.
Thank you! But it was simple once I figured it out.
You have a lot of faith in me, don't you?
So, what's the code?
Looking at Stalinets' letter again- all of these characters can also be music notes. A, B, G...
You think she sent you a song?
I know in my heart she did.
Well, you'd better play it, see what you think.
*ALARM*
I will as soon as these witches give us the chance.
@BATTLE
*violin music*
Hey, that sounds pretty good. Is that another one of your improvisations?
Nyet, Cap! It's the song that Stalinets sent me.

Fields.MenuText: It's haunting.
It's beautiful.
I don't know if I like it...

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, you don't have to. I'm just glad you're listening.
Thank you, Captain. I just hope my playing does it justice.
It does sound that way, doesn't it?
Ah! What's that you're playing?
Do you recognize it?
Da, it is a lullaby. Bayu Bayushki Bayu...
It's a lullaby? It sounds like a dirge.
Mmhm. My mother sang it to me when I was a baby.
"Bayu, bayushki, bayu, do not lie on edge of bed, or grey wolf will bite you on side and drag you to forest..."
That's not morbid at all.
I think it's touching. Don't you see what this means, Cap?
Get me up to speed.
Stalinets sent me a song a mother would sing to her children.
Well, thank you. You reminded me of my childhood. Put a smile on my face.
Any time.
We've got a few more stragglers. Let's clean house.
@BATTLE
She really does care, Cap. She really does care...
Urgh.
What's wrong?
We're in American radio space again.
What's so bad about that?
Some *ch'mo* down in the torpedo bay has a radio, a love for American music, and no volume control.
If I have to hear "Sing, Sing, Sing" or "Won't You Be My Victory Belle" one more time, it will be too soon.

Fields.MenuText: I hate that song too. It's so... insipid.
Swing is good, and I won't hear you say anything against it.
You really don't like American music?

Fields.DialogueText: Right? Why would they ever write a love song about *us*?
It's not swing I have a problem with. Necessarily.
It's not American music I have a problem with.
I hate music that doesn't carry any genuine emotion. Music is the universal language.
If the only thing you're conveying is vague sentimentality, what is the point of writing music at all?
Sometimes people fall in love, don't they?
Hm.
And besides, you get really sentimental about your daughters.
That's different, Captain...
Really?
*ALARM*
Ack, more witches.
Look on the bright side - they'll drown out the radio.
@BATTLE
We're picking up a distress signal, Captain!
All the way out here? That's strange.
It could be a Morgana trap.
Yeah. It could. What can you tell me about it?
I just... This is a Soviet distress signal.
Yes?
If there was something out here... I'd like to think I'd know about it.

Fields.MenuText: You *are* a Soviet Belle...
Some things are top secret.
Your bosses *do* like to keep secrets.

Fields.DialogueText: ...I know. I don't have that kind of clearance.
... Especially from me, Cap.
Exactly! I've patrolled the Arctic Circle for so long...
I think you're right. Something smells fishy.
... *But* if people are in danger, I don't want to leave them for dead.
... Yes, Cap. That would be a scummy thing to do.
Morganas at nine-o-clock, sir.
Let's knock 'em dead.
@BATTLE
Captain, look! There *is* a Soviet base out here!
Good. So the distress call wasn't spoofed.
Unless it's abandoned.

Fields.MenuText: You're a pessimist, huh?
Don't give up hope!
If it's abandoned, we'll get out ASAP.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, Cap, I never had any.
I'm also *right*.
Let's just hope we don't lose anyone on the way.
Circle around the side. Let's try to flank 'em.
On it, Cap.
@BATTLE
Or you're biased.
Not on my watch.
There's only a few left. Let's finish this!
@BATTLE
Kapitan! You came just in time. Our defenses couldn't hold up. We're scientists, not soldiers.
The base is trying to contact us, Cap.
Patch them through.
Just doing our duty.
Is there anything else you need, while we're here?
Well, it's very lonely out here. Would some of you mind coming in for a spell? Just for some tea.
I don't like this, Cap. It could be a trap.

Fields.MenuText: You sure? They seem friendly.
This is a Soviet base and you're flying Soviet colors.
You're being real twitchy all of a sudden.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, but...
Do you really distrust your own people this much?
They must have a reason for that. This place is locked down so tight.
And you shouldn't be? This smells like rotten herring.
... When someone distrusts you, it makes it difficult to give them your trust in return.
Of course. But these aren't the people who've hurt you.
... No, Captain.
Let's get inside, all right? They said they had tea...
You know how to motivate a girl.
That was a perfectly pleasant visit, don't you think?
Hm. Surprisingly so.
There's just one thing I don't get, Captain...
Yes?
Why put a research base out on the ice?
There were a lot of warning signs. Something about fission?
Yes, but even dangerous research would be easier to do closer to home, nyet?

Fields.MenuText: You have a point.
If it's too dangerous, it's best to keep far away.
There's no space for it, with all the gulags.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't joke about things like that, Cap.
Who knows, one of us might quote-unquote 'disappear' one day.
There's miles and miles of nothing in Siberia.
Surely they could use some of that space?
Of course I do. Something bad is going to happen.
I can taste it on the air; can't you?
I guess we'll never know.
Maybe they're doing research on something nasty.
I guess. It doesn't sit right with me, Cap.
Few things do.
Hey, now! I can be perfectly content. Blissful, even.
... It's easier when you're around, Cap.
Well, thank you.
*ALARM*
Right on schedule, huh?
Let's get them out of the way.
@BATTLE
Hey, guess what?
Are you going to give me more bad news?
No, it's good news for once.
You're pulling my leg, Cap.
Not a chance. We got a commendation from a Russian admiral.
Let me see.
... Wait, this is for saving a 'village' near Anadyr?
Apparently so.
We haven't been anywhere near Anadyr in months.
Nope.
Do you think this is about... that research base?

Fields.MenuText: Maybe. Who can say?
Yes. And they don't want us to talk.
A commendation is a commendation.

Fields.DialogueText: If it is, I'm sure this is a warning.
Of course not. I'm trying to put it out of mind.
Perhaps so, but it can also be blackmail.
They don't want us to talk about what we've seen.
Maybe we can use this to your advantage.
Oh? How so?
You can use it as leverage. Maybe write to a Fleet admiral who isn't one of your bosses.
Isn't part of the Soviet fleet, you mean?
Exactly. Tell them you want to see your daughters again, and that there's been some kind of mix-up.
That could work, honestly...
You never know if you don't try.
Thank heavens the Fleet is set up the way it is.
-- I mean!
Figure of speech?
Figure of speech.
*ALARM*
Finally, some bad news.
Were you *worried* there wouldn't be any?
Just waiting for the other shoe to drop.
@BATTLE
Back to civilization!
Finally. I was starting to think we'd be out on the ice forever.
Can I trouble you for a favor, Cap?

Fields.MenuText: What's the favor?
I'm listening.
Anything for you, mate.

Fields.DialogueText: I need you to send another letter for me. It's to the Admirality.
About your daughters?
Da. I want to see them again, and ... well... like you said, we have leverage.
Ah, thank you! It means a lot that you care.
I'd be happy to. Your daughters mean a lot to you.
Oh, nothing much.
Thank you, Captain! We'll see how it goes.
It'll turn out all right. You'll see.
*ALARM*
Will your optimism or my pessimism win, Cap?
Let's find out.
@BATTLE
I got a letter back, Cap!
From the Admirality?
Yes. I'm so scared to open it...
I'm here for you. Go ahead.
Agh, I can't look. What does it say, Cap?
It says that... Rear Admiral Ivanov acted without official permission in keeping you separated...
Something something "subject to discipline," something something "clearance to visit..."
... And a rendezvous date for you and the L-Class subs, in Leningrad in a couple weeks.
Cap, I....  I don't know what to say.
I didn't want to make trouble for anyone. Especially since naval discipline can be... rough...
But I get to see my daughters again. And that... I thought...

Fields.MenuText: It's all right, Bezbozhnik. You're all right.
Don't feel too bad about it. He was out of line.
Family's more important.

Fields.DialogueText: I know. ...I know.
Still. I don't want anyone hurt for my sake.
He'll probably just wind up pushing papers. Or peeling potatoes.
Of course. And my daughters... I can't just leave them because of someone else's whims. Even if they are my commander.
I'll never do that to you. Promise.
Thank you, Cap. ...I can't express how grateful I am...
You don't need to. It's okay. You're okay.
But still, I-
*ALARM*
Never a dull moment, huh?
Never.
@BATTLE
Every time we go for shore leave, there's Morganas around the port.
They're like bloody seagulls, Cap. Let's chase them off.
@BATTLE
Well, this is it. Leningrad. Are you ready?
As I'll ever be. It's been too long...
So what are you waiting for? Go!
Ah, I'm nervous. What if they're upset with me?
I could have tried harder to talk to them. To reach out.

Fields.MenuText: And you would have gotten them in trouble.
You did the best you could. They'll understand.
What's the worst that can happen?

Fields.DialogueText: Believe me, Cap, you don't want to know. I just hope they see things differently than I do.
... I hope they'll see it as kindly as you do, Captain.
Yes. ...That doesn't mean they'll understand, though.
I bet they will. Look, here they come.
Girls! Oh, you've gotten so *big!*
Leninets, is that a new cannon? Chartist, you cut your hair-
Heh. Somehow, I think they'll be all right.
Bezbozhnik! You look happy.
I take it things went well, then?
Better than I'd dared to hope. Thank you.
Any time. I'm just happy you got to see them.
I'm over the moon, Captain.
Carbonari gave me an entire book of folk songs, and they all signed it. And we had dinner in Leninets' mess, and...

Fields.MenuText: It sounds like you had a great time.
It must be nice to catch up with your kids.
You got what you were after. Well done.

Fields.DialogueText: I did. ....I love them so, so much, Captain. We're a family again.
It was more than catching up. It was being a family again.
It's more than that, Captain. I got my family back.
And I have you to thank for it.
You're welcome. I'm happy to help.
Wait. Captain-
Yes?
... Do you remember what I said, earlier, about trust?
"It's difficult to trust someone when they don't trust you."
Da. And out of the gate,  I didn't trust you.
The other commanding officers I've dealt with, they were either Soviet or British. The Soviets needed me, but did not trust me.
And the British... they did not need me or trust me. In their eyes, I was a traitor. Brainwashed, kidnapped. You understand how it is.
You are the first captain I've had who, out of the gate, assumed I was competent and loyal. And, more than that...
You're the first person in a very long time who cared about what I had to say.
... Of course. Why wouldn't I?
You trusted me. Even though I did not trust you. And I will never be able to thank you enough for that.
Well, actions speak louder than words. C'mon!
*ALARM*
Right behind you, Captain.
@BATTLE
This is the first time I've had all my daughters in one place. All of us together.
Do you understand how much that means to me? To *us*?
Captain! What's that I see by the coffee pot?
Do my eyes deceive me, or is that a samovar?
It *is* a samovar. You wanted one so badly, I couldn't say no.
And? What do you think?
The tea *is* much hotter.  And I think it tastes better.
Hm.
You look *so smug* right now.
You listened. What can I say?
You know, there's an old superstition...
*sip*
I don't remember which side of my heritage it's from...
If your tea leaves float to the surface of your cup, you will find true love in a year.
Where'd your tea leaves go, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: To the top. How about that.
To the bottom, I'm afraid.

Fields.DialogueText: But I don't think it'll take a year to find my love.
Is that so? Well, I look forward to it.
Ah, well. There's always next year, Captain.
I'll help you keep an eye out. What are friends for?
Whatever happens next year, I'm lucky to have a Belle I can trust by my side.
I'll drink to that, Captain!
